questions.Q: A system consist of an homogeneous sphere of mass $$m$$ and radius $$R$$ suspended from a light string of length $$L$$. If $$R=\frac{L}{4}$$ and the sphere is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the sphere is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{mgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the sphere about the pivot and $$h=L+R$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the sphere from the pivot. Using the parallel axis theorem, $$\\I_0=\frac{2}{5}mR^2+m(L+R)^2\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ and using $$R=\frac{1}{3}L$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{41}{30}\frac{L}{g}}$$

questions.Q: A homegeneus rod of mass $$m$$ and length $$L$$ is pivoted at $$P$$. If the rod is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the rod is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{mgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the rod about the pivot and $$h=\frac{1}{2}L$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the rod from the pivot. In this case $$I_0=\frac{1}{3}mL^2$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}\frac{L}{g}}$$

questions.Q: A homegeneus rod of mass $$m$$ and length $$L$$ is pivoted at $$P$$ which is a distance $$a=\frac{1}{3}L$$ away from the center of the rod. If the rod is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the rod is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{mgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the rod about the pivot and $$h=a=\frac{1}{3}L$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the rod from the pivot. $$\\$$To find $$I_0$$ we use the parallel axis theorem $$\\I_0=\frac{1}{12}mL^2+ma^2\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{7}{12}\frac{L}{g}}$$

questions.Q: A system consists of an homogeneous disk of mass $$M$$ and radius $$R$$ attached to the end of an homogeneous thin rod of length $$L$$ and mass $$m$$. The rod is pivot at one end and is free to rotate about the pivot $$P$$ without friction. If $$M=3m$$ and $$R=\frac{1}{5}L$$ and the system is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the system is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{M_tgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the system (rod plus disk) about the pivot and $$h$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the system from the pivot. $$\\I_0=I_{rod}+I_{disk}\\$$ where $$\\I_{rod}=\frac{1}{3}mL^2\\$$ and $$\\ I_{disk}=\frac{1}{2}MR^2+M(L+R)^2\\$$ To find $$I_{disk}$$ we have used the parallel axis theorem.$$\\$$ Let us find $$h\\$$ $$h=\frac{m\frac{L}{2}+M(L+R)}{m+M}\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ and using $$R=\frac{1}{5}L$$, $$M_t=m+3m=4m$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{1339}{1230}\frac{L}{g}}$$

questions.Q: A system consists of an homogeneous sphere of mass $$M$$ and radius $$R$$ attached to the end of an homogeneous thin rod of length $$L$$ and mass $$m$$. The rod is pivot at one end and is free to rotate about the pivot $$P$$ without friction. If $$M=3m$$ and $$R=\frac{1}{5}L$$ and the system is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the system is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{M_tgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the system (rod plus sphere) about the pivot and $$h$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the system to the pivot. $$\\I_0=I_{rod}+I_{sphere}\\$$ where $$\\I_{rod}=\frac{1}{3}mL^2\\$$ and $$\\ I_{sphere}=\frac{2}{5}MR^2+M(L+R)^2\\$$ To find $$I_{sphere}$$ we have used the parallel axis theorem.$$\\$$ Let us find $$h\\$$ $$h=\frac{m\frac{L}{2}+M(L+R)}{m+M}\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ and using $$R=\frac{1}{5}L$$, $$M_t=m+3m=4m$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{6677}{6150}\frac{L}{g}}$$

questions.Q: A system consists of a rigid massless thin rod and three identical tiny balls of mass $$m$$ each one fixed to the rod. The balls are equally spaced from each other as shown. If the rod is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the system is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{M_tgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the system (three balls) about the pivot and $$h$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the system from the pivot. Given that the balls are tiny, these can be considered as point like particles, so $$\\I_0=m\Big(\frac{1}{3}L\Big)^2+ m\Big(\frac{2}{3}L\Big)^2+mL^2\\$$Let us find $$h\\$$ $$h=\frac{m\frac{L}{3}+m\frac{2L}{3}+mL}{m+m+m}=\frac{2}{3}L\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ and taking $$M_t=3m$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{7}{9}\frac{L}{g}}$$

questions.Q: A system consists of a rigid massless thin rod and four identical tiny balls of mass $$m$$ each one fixed to the rod. The balls are equally spaced from each other as shown. If the rod is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the system is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{M_tgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the system (three balls) about the pivot and $$h$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the system from the pivot. Given that the balls are tiny, these can be considered as point like particles, so $$\\I_0=m\Big(\frac{1}{2}L\Big)^2+ m\Big(\frac{2}{4}L\Big)^2+ m\Big(\frac{3}{4}L\Big)^2+mL^2\\$$Let us find $$h\\$$ $$h=\frac{m\frac{L}{4}+m\frac{2L}{4}+m\frac{3L}{4}+mL}{m+m+m+m}=\frac{5}{8}L\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ and taking $$M_t=4m$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{7}{12}\frac{L}{g}}$$

questions.Q: Four identical thin rods of mass $$m$$ each one are the sides of a rigid square as shown. The square is pivoted at $$P$$. If friction is neglected and the square is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the system is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{M_tgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the system about the pivot and $$h$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the system from the pivot. The moment of inertia of the system is the sum of the moments of inertia of the four rods. Thus, $$\\I_0=I_1+I_2+I_3+I_4\\$$ where $$\\I_1=I_2=\frac{1}{3}mL^2\\I_3=I_4=\frac{1}{12}mL^2+mc^2\\$$ To find $$I_3$$ and $$I_4$$ we have used the parallel axis theorem. $$\\c=\sqrt{L^2+(\frac{1}{2}L)^2}=\sqrt{\frac{5}{4}}L\\$$ The value of $$h$$ is: $$\\h=L\cos(\frac{\pi}{4})=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}L\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ and taking $$M_t=4m$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{5\sqrt{2}}{6}\frac{L}{g}}$$

questions.Q: Two thin rods of lengths $$a$$ and $$b$$ are cut from a uniform long rod and fixed perpendicularly  as shown in the figure. One end of the rod is pivoted at $$P$$. If friction is neglected, $$a=\frac{2}{3}b$$ and the system is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the system is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{M_tgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the system about the pivot and $$h$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the system from the pivot. The moment of inertia of the system is the sum of the moments of inertia of the two rods. Thus, $$\\I_0=I_1+I_2\\$$ where $$\\I_1=\frac{1}{3}mb^2\\I_2=\frac{1}{12}Ma^2+Mb^2\\$$To find $$I_2$$ we have used the parallel axis theorem. $$\\$$ The value of the masses are: $$\\ m=\lambda b\\M=\lambda a\\$$ and therefore $$M_t=m+M$$ where $$\lambda$$ is the mass per unit length which is the same for both rods. The value of $$h$$ is: $$\\h= \frac{m\frac{b}{2}+Mb}{m+M}\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ and taking $$a=\frac{2}{3}b$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{166}{189}\frac{b}{g}}$$

questions.Q: Two thin rods of lengths $$a$$ and $$b$$ are cut from a uniform long rod and fixed perpendicularly as shown in the figure. One end of the rod is pivoted at $$P$$. If friction is neglected, $$a=\frac{1}{2}b$$ and the system is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the system is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{M_tgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the system about the pivot and $$h$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the system from the pivot. The moment of inertia of the system is the sum of the moments of inertia of the two rods. Thus, $$\\I_0=I_1+I_2\\$$ where $$\\I_1=\frac{1}{3}mb^2\\I_2=\frac{1}{12}Ma^2+Md^2\\$$ To find $$I_2$$ we have used the parallel axis theorem. $$\\$$ The value of the masses are: $$\\ m=\lambda b\\M=\lambda a\\$$ and therefore $$M_t=m+M$$ where $$\lambda$$ is the mass per unit length which is the same for both rods. Let us find $$h$$. To do this, we first need to find the $$x$$ and $$y$$ coordinates of the center of mass (point C): $$\\x_{cm}= \frac{m\frac{b}{2}+Mb}{m+M}\\ y_{cm}= \frac{m(0)+M\frac{a}{2}}{m+M}\\$$ Thus, $$\\ h=\sqrt{x_{cm}^2 +y_{cm}^2}\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ and taking $$a=\frac{1}{2}b$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{7}{\sqrt{65}}\frac{b}{g}}$$

questions.Q: A system consist of an homogeneous ring of mass $$m$$ and radius $$R$$ pivoted at $$P$$. The center of mass of the ring is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the ring is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{mgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the ring about the pivot and $$h=R$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the ring from the pivot. Using the parallel axis theorem, $$\\I_0=mR^2+mR^2=2mR^2\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{2R}{g}}$$

questions.Q: A system consist of an homogeneous disk of mass $$m$$ and radius $$R$$ pivoted at $$P$$. The center of mass of the disk is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the disk is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{mgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the disk about the pivot and $$h=R$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the disk from the pivot. Using the parallel axis theorem, $$\\I_0=\frac{1}{2}mR^2+mR^2=\frac{3}{2}mR^2\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}\frac{R}{g}}$$

questions.Q: Three identical thin rods, each of length $$L$$ and mass $$m$$ are welded to form an equilateral triangle. The assembly is pivoted at $$P$$. If friction is neglected and the triangle is initially displaced to one side by a small angle $$\theta_0$$ and released from rest, the period of small oscillations of the triangle is:
questions.E: For small angles of oscillation, the time period of the physical pendulum is $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I_0}{mgh}}\\$$ where $$I_0$$ is the moment of inertia of the triangle about the pivot and $$h$$ is the distance of the center of mass of the triangle from the pivot. $$\\I_0=I_1+I_2+I_3\\I_1=I_2=\frac{1}{3}mL^2\\$$ using the parallel axis theorem, $$\\I_3=\frac{1}{12}mL^2+m(L\cos\frac{\pi}{6})^2=\frac{1}{3}mL^2\\$$ By symmetry, the center of mass of the triangle is along the x axis and its distance from the pivot is given by $$\\h=\frac{m\frac{1}{2}L\cos\frac{\pi}{6}+m\frac{1}{2}L\cos\frac{\pi}{6}+mL\cos\frac{\pi}{6}}{3m}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}L\\$$ Plugging these quantities into $$T$$ we have, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\frac{L}{g}}$$
